newsitem.title: ITALY: Italian Antitrust head Amato confirms resignation.
newsitem.headline: Italian Antitrust head Amato confirms resignation.

text.p: Giuliano Amato officially confirmed on Thursday his intention to resign as Chairman of Italy's Antitrust authority before the end of this year to return to an academic career.

Presenting the Antitrust body's annual report in parliament, Amato, a law professor and former prime minister, said he would resign by December and noted that the seven-year term of the other four Antitrust executives also expired this year.
Amato has said he intends to return to teaching at the European University Institute in Florence which recently conferred on him a Chair in Legal Institutions and Public Policy.
Amato, a former member of the Socialist Party which was discredited in Italy's corruption scandals, was prime minister from June 1992 until April 1993.

His coalition government collapsed under the weight of the scandals but he himself earned wide international respect for his handling of the Italian economy, including in the areas of privatisation and attempts to rein in high public spending.
